node.title: Question about SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have a question about using SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC to set the initial condition of circle. I want to generate a initial condition like this,

In the most part of the square model, the initial c is set as 0, however, in some small circles, the initial condition should be set as larger values. How can I randomly generate some values for the circle's initial concentration in some range? I saw that in all the examples shown in SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC webpage, the initial concentration can only be set as one specific value. How can I set different values for each circle's concentration? Or I can only set the same value for the two circles?

Thank you,
Best,

You could try with CoupledValueFunctionIC, RandomIC, SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC. Use 1 temp initial variable to populate random values with RandomIC. Then use another temp variable to create circles shown in Fig with SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC; use 1 and 0 values for this case. Finally, user CoupledValueFunctionIC for main variable and multiply two temp variables. I hope that it may work.

node.title: Error message 'Variables/c/InitialCondition1' does not have an associated "Action".
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
When I ran my simulation, i got this error message.
56: section 'Variables/c/InitialCondition1' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
68: section 'Variables/c/InitialCondition2' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
80: section 'Variables/c/InitialCondition3' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
92: section 'Variables/c/InitialCondition4' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
What is the problem of this? How to correct it?
I attached my input file here,
file.txt
Thank you very much,
Best,

Hello
Please follow the tutorial again.
These are very basic questions, you are simply not following the syntax of a moose input.
If should be something like:
[Variables]
  [c]
    [InitialCondition]
       type = ...
    []
  []
[]

Guillaume
I changed to this and it works now.
this is fine too

node.title: Error message"Task add_mesh_generator is not registered to build MooseMesh derived objects"
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
When I ran my simulation, I got this error message, why is this? How to correct it?

I also attached my input file here.
file.txt
Thank you very much,
Best,

Hello
You need to use GeneratedMeshGenerator not GeneratedMesh
Guillaume

node.title: Using Dirac kernels with reporters
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am using a method of perfectly matched discrete layers to solve a simple problem in 2D. Note that I have successfully used the same technique to solve 1D problems and it works fine. But I have huge inconsistent results with the 2D case. The results are blowing up and not converging as expected.
I have the following results: The sampled variable at the interface before the iteration is u = 3.92415 and 3.88704, xflux = 0.196009 and 0.19600, v = 0 and 0, xflux_v = 0 and 0. After the iteration, u = 3.92415 and 3.88704, xflux = 0.196009 and 0.196009, xflux_v = 0.72031 and 0.72031, v = 67.38297 and 67.37507, xflux_v = 0.72031 and 0.72031.
These results are severely not correct and they are obtained from the following files:
First subsystem:
[Mesh]
  [./generated]
    type = CartesianMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    dx = '1 1'
    ix = '32 1'
    dy = '0.1'
    iy = '1'
    subdomain_id = '1 2'
  [../]
[]


[Variables]
  [u]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [xflux]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [yflux]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = u
    diffusivity = 1
  []
    [reaction]
    type =  Reaction
    variable = u
    rate = 0.25
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [xfluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = -1
    variable = xflux
    diffusion_variable = u
    component = x
  []
  [yfluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = -1
    variable = yflux
    diffusion_variable = u
    component = y
  []

[]

[DiracKernels]
  [point_source]
    type = ConstantPointSource
    variable = u
    value = 1
    point = '0.8 0.0 0'
    point_not_found_behavior = 'ERROR'
  []

  
  [unode1_interface]
    type = ReporterPointSource
    variable = u
    value_name = 'csv_v_interface/v'
    x_coord_name = 'csv_v_interface/x'
    y_coord_name = 'csv_v_interface/y'
    z_coord_name = 'csv_v_interface/z'
    #point_name = 'csv_v_interface/x'
    point_not_found_behavior = 'ERROR'
  []
  [xfluxnode1_interface]
    type = ReporterPointSource
    variable = u
    value_name = 'csv_flux_interface/xflux_v'
    x_coord_name = 'csv_flux_interface/x'
    y_coord_name = 'csv_flux_interface/y'
    z_coord_name = 'csv_flux_interface/z'
    point_not_found_behavior = 'ERROR'
  []

[]

[BCs]
  [leftBC] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 0
  []
  [rightBC] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 0
  []
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [u_interface]
    type = LineValueSampler
    variable = 'u'
    start_point = '0.999999 0 0'
    end_point = '0.999999 0.099999 0'
    scaling =   1.0625 #0.033203125   
    num_points = 2
    sort_by = x
  []
  [flux_interface]
    type = LineValueSampler
    variable = 'xflux'
    start_point = '0.999999 0 0'
    end_point = '0.999999 0.099999 0'
    scaling = -0.05  
    num_points = 2
    sort_by = x
  []
  [csv_v_interface]
    type = CSVReader
    csv_file = left_subdomain_pmdl_schwarz_new_out_sub0_v_interface_0001.csv
  []
  [csv_flux_interface]
    type = CSVReader
    csv_file = left_subdomain_pmdl_schwarz_new_out_sub0_flux_interface_0001.csv
  []
[]


[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'

  fixed_point_max_its = 1000
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  fixed_point_rel_tol = 1e-16
  fixed_point_abs_tol = 1e-10

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'

  [Quadrature]
    type = 'GAUSS'
    custom_blocks = '1 2'    
    custom_orderX = 'FIRST CONSTANT'
    custom_orderY = 'FIRST FIRST'
  []

[]


[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  console = true
[]


[MultiApps]
  [sub]
    type = FullSolveMultiApp
    #positions = '0.5 0 0'
    input_files = 'right_subdomain_pmdl_schwarz_new.i'
    execute_on = 'timestep_begin'
  []
[]


Second subsystem:
[Mesh]
  [./generated]
    type = CartesianMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    dx = '1 1'
    ix = '1 32'
    dy = '0.1'
    iy = '1'
    subdomain_id = '1 2'
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [v]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [xflux_v]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [yflux_v]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = v
    diffusivity = 1
  []
  [reaction]
    type =  Reaction
    variable = v
    rate = 0.25
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [xfluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = -1
    variable = xflux_v
    diffusion_variable = v
    component = x
  []
  [yfluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = -1
    variable = yflux_v
    diffusion_variable = v
    component = y
  []
[]

[DiracKernels]
  [vnode1_interface]
    type = ReporterPointSource
    variable = v
    value_name = 'csv_u_interface/u'
    x_coord_name = 'csv_u_interface/x'
    y_coord_name = 'csv_u_interface/y'
    z_coord_name = 'csv_u_interface/z'
    #point_name = 'csv_v_interface/x'
    point_not_found_behavior = 'ERROR'
  []
  [xfluxnode1_interface]
    type = ReporterPointSource
    variable = v
    value_name = 'csv_flux_interface/xflux'
    x_coord_name = 'csv_flux_interface/x'
    y_coord_name = 'csv_flux_interface/y'
    z_coord_name = 'csv_flux_interface/z'
    #point_name = 'csv_v_interface/x'
    point_not_found_behavior = 'ERROR'
  []
[]

[BCs]

  [leftBC] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = v
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 0
  []


[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [v_interface]
    type = LineValueSampler
    variable = 'v'
    start_point = '1.000001 0 0'
    end_point = '1.000001 0.099999 0'
    scaling =  1.0625 #0.033203125    
    num_points = 2
    sort_by = x
  []
  [flux_interface]
    type = LineValueSampler
    variable = 'xflux_v'
    start_point = '1.000001 0 0'
    end_point = '1.000001 0.099999 0'
    scaling = 0.05  
    num_points = 2
    sort_by = x
  []
  [csv_u_interface]
    type = CSVReader
    csv_file = left_subdomain_pmdl_schwarz_new_out_u_interface_0001.csv
  []
  [csv_flux_interface]
    type = CSVReader
    csv_file = left_subdomain_pmdl_schwarz_new_out_flux_interface_0001.csv
  []
[]


[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'



  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
  
  [Quadrature]
    type = 'GAUSS'
    custom_blocks = '1 2'    
    custom_orderX = 'CONSTANT FIRST'
    custom_orderY = 'FIRST FIRST'
  []
[]



[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  console = true
[]

Note that I have a locally modified libmesh that applied quadrature in different directions as I need the midpoint rule in the domain with a unit length discretization.
I will appreciate why the results obtained from these files are not consistent.
A simple 1D of the problem is given as follows and I have used the same PMDL technique to solve it without using the reporter since I can simply manually post-process the result to transfer without writing it in a file:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 1000
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 2
[]

[Variables]
  [u]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [flux]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = u
    diffusivity = 1
  []
  [reaction]
    type =  Reaction
    variable = u
    rate = 0.25
  []
[]

[DiracKernels]
  [point_source]
    type = ConstantPointSource
    variable = u
    value = 1.0
    point = '0.8 0 0'
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = -1
    variable = flux
    diffusion_variable = u
    component = x
  []
[]

[BCs]
 [leftBC] 
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 0
  []
  
[]



[Executioner]

  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

  fixed_point_max_its = 500
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  fixed_point_rel_tol = 1e-16
  fixed_point_abs_tol = 1e-10

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  #csv = true
  console = true
[]

Thank you !!

Hello
Does this work fine with a regular quadrature?
Basically, are the results wrong because of the new quadrature you made? Or is this something else?
Guillaume
I have a similar issue without specifying the quadrature block. It should be something else.

So Gauss is the default quadrature anyway, so specifying
  [Quadrature]
    type = 'GAUSS'
    custom_blocks = '1 2'    
    custom_orderX = 'CONSTANT FIRST'
    custom_orderY = 'FIRST FIRST'
  []

only worked to change the order. If you changed the Gauss quadrature, you would be using the changed one whether you specify it or not.
I would try a non-modified quadrature first.
If you're confident the problems are not coming from your modified quadrature, can you specify what the issue is with the results?

I have validated the implementation of the quadrature rule by using it on a rotated simple anisotropic 2D problem in different directions.
That being said, consider the results obtained from these files:


You can notice the huge discrepancy between the results. At least, the result should be pretty close to each other and to the reference result

From the sampled values before the start of the coupling is u = 3.92415 and 3.88704, xflux = 0.196009 and 0.19600, v = 0 and 0, xflux_v = 0 and 0. After the iteration, both u and xflux values do not change while xflux_v = 0.72031 and 0.72031 and v = 67.38297 and 67.37507. My worry is justified since both u and xflux values do not change even after the simulation, but v has a drastic increase in value.

Are these results converged? Like mesh-wise
What are u & v physically?
Can you decouple u & v, keeping one constant? To verify the equation for u and v separately

Both u and v physically are basically the same variable in two different subdomains.
So, I tried by basically a 2D version of a 1D problem with the force equally on the nodes, and comparing it with my 1D result which agrees.
However, that involves me manually postprocessing the result and this method adds several lines to the input files, even for one element (two nodes) in the y-direction.
That was why I tried using reporters to allow me to specify any number of discretizations.

Reporter is a good idea to postprocess.
I would try to s simplify the problem until you get the expected result. This will help you narrow down where the issue here.

I tried narrowing down my problem to a simple case of having one element with two nodes in the y-direction. Then I manually post-process the result as I want it, before using the same construct for the VectorPostprocessor, after which I could get several numbers of discretization in the y-direction.
Thank you.

node.title: The rotation of the elastic tensor
node.bodyText: In the ComputeElasticityTensor class, it seems that C_ijkl, rotation_matrix and euler angles can only be set to specific values. If the material direction is tangential to the circumference, as shown in the figure, how can I rotate the elasticity tensor accordingly? Is there a convenient method to achieve this?

node.title: Convergence problem (maybe the Jacobian issue?)
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose experts,
I have a convergence problem in my input.
In detail, I set T(temperature) as an Auxkernel before setting it as a variable.
At T=300, 400K, 550K, 600K, and 900K my simulation converges very well.
However, I cannot understand the reason why, at T=450K, and 500K, my simulation does not converge.
I am curious if the reason is that my own kernel "NernstElec" has the wrong QpJacobian.
So, the question is

Why does not my simulation converges? the reason?
If the wrong Jacobian is the reason for the problem, can you help me to correct it?
I am a beginner in this area so I am not sure if my Jacobian is right.

Here is my "NernstElec.C" file.
It is for the second term of RHS. (N: variable, V(elec): coupled_variable)

For residual, it calculates (constant)(_grad_test)(_grad_elec)*(N)
#include "NernstElec.h"                                                                                                                                                                     
registerMooseObject("test7App",NernstElec);

InputParameters
NernstElec::validParams()
{
  InputParameters params = Kernel::validParams();
    params.addClassDescription("The Laplacian operator ($-\\nabla \\cdot \\nabla u$), with the weak "
                                                         "form of $(\\nabla \\phi_i, \\nabla u_h)$.");
    params.addCoupledVar("elec", "electrical potential");
    params.addParam<MaterialPropertyName>(
            "eDkT",
            "eDkT",
            "Material property.");
    // params.addRequiredCoupledVar("conductivity","conductivity");
  return params;
}

NernstElec::NernstElec(const InputParameters & parameters)
    : Kernel(parameters),
    _grad_elec(coupledGradient("elec")),
    _elec_var(coupled("elec")),
    _elec_cond(getMaterialProperty<Real>("eDkT"))

    // _elec_cond(coupledValue("conductivity"))
    // _grad_T(coupledGradient("Temperature"))
{
}



Real
NernstElec::computeQpResidual()
{
  return _elec_cond[_qp] * _grad_test[_i][_qp] * _u[_qp] * _grad_elec[_qp];
}

//Real
//NernstElec::computeQpJacobian()
//{
//  return _elec_cond[_qp] * _grad_test[_i][_qp] * _phi[_j][_qp] * _grad_elec[_qp] ;
//}

For your information, I attached my input file.
########## Global Parameters ########## 
xmax = 35
ymax = 20
#######################################

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 35
  ny = 20
  nz = 0
  xmin = 0
  xmax = ${xmax}
  ymin = 0
  ymax = ${ymax}
  zmin = 0
  zmax = 0
  elem_type = QUAD8
[]

[Functions]
  [./bc_func]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    data_file = './vsweep.csv'
    format = columns
    scale_factor = 1.0
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [./N]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]

  [./V]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 0.0
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [./N_IC]
    type = MultiBoundingBoxIC
    corners = '0.0 0.0 0   '
    opposite_corners = '9.0 20.0 0'
    inside = '1.2'
    outside = 0.0
    variable = N
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [V_top]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = V
    function = bc_func # GND
    boundary = 'top'
  []

  [V_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = V
    value = 0.0
    boundary = 'bottom'
  []
[]

[Kernels]

  ########### Phase-field ############

  [./Matdiff_D_del2_N]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = N
    diffusivity = Diff_coeff
  [../]

  [./Nernst]
    type = NernstElec
    variable = N
    elec = V
    eDkT = eDkT
  [../]


  [./PFM_time]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = N
  [../]

  ########## Phase-field END ##########

  ########## Electrical ###############

  [./Matdiff_sig_del2_V]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = V
    diffusivity = 'electrical_conductivity'
  [../]

  ########## Electrical END ###########

[]





[Materials]
  [./Diff_coeff]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name  = Diff_coeff
    coupled_variables = 'T'
    constant_names       = 'D0     E_A_D    kB        ' #[eV]  [eV/K]  [K]
    constant_expressions = '2e+11  1.0      8.617e-5'
    expression = 'D0*exp(-E_A_D/(kB*T))' #[nm^2/s]
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./eDkT]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = eDkT
    coupled_variables = 'T'
    constant_names       = 'kB       ' #[V/K]
    constant_expressions = '8.617e-5'
    material_property_names = 'Diff_coeff'
    expression = 'Diff_coeff/(kB*T)' #[nm^2/(s*V)]
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./electrical_conductivity_INS]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables = 'N E_AC_elec T'
    property_name = 'electrical_conductivity'
    constant_names =        'sig_H    sig_L     kB'       
    constant_expressions =  '1.0e-6   2.860e-4  8.617e-5' #[1/(ohm*nm)] [1/(ohm*nm)] [eV/K]
#    material_property_names = 'h'
#    function = '(1/cm_2_nm) * if(eta <= 0.5-w/2,Crys,if(eta<0.5+w/2, Amor + 0.5*(Crys+Amor)*(1.0+cos(pi*(eta-0.5+w/2)/w)),Amor))'  # [1/(ohm*nm)]
#    function = '(sig_L - sig_H) * eta + sig_H'  # [1/(ohm*nm)]
#    function = 'if(c <= 0.5-w/2, sig_H, if(c > 0.5+w/2, sig_L, sig_H + 0.5 * (sig_L-sig_H) * (1 - cos(pi/w * (c-0.5+w/2)))))'
#    expression = 'sig_H*(1-h)+sig_L*h'
    expression = '((sig_L-sig_H)/1.2*N+sig_H)*exp(-E_AC_elec/(kB*T))'
    outputs = exodus
#    block = 2
  [../]

[]

[AuxVariables]

  [./T]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [./InitialCondition] #Temperature
        type = ConstantIC
        value = 450.0
    [../]
  []

  ########## Electric ##########
  [Ex]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [Ey]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [J]
    family = NEDELEC_ONE
    order = FIRST
  []

  [Jy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [E_AC_elec]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  ######## Electric END ########

[]


[AuxKernels]
  ########## Electric ##########
  [Ex_aux]
    type = PotentialToFieldAux
    variable = Ex
    gradient_variable = V
    sign = negative
    component = x
  []

  [Ey_aux]
    type = PotentialToFieldAux
    variable = Ey
    gradient_variable = V
    sign = negative
    component = y
  []

  [current_density]
    type = CurrentDensity
    variable = J
    potential = V
  []

  [Jy]
    type = VectorVariableComponentAux
    variable = Jy
    vector_variable = J
    component = y
  []

  [E_AC_elec_aux]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = E_AC_elec
    coupled_variables = 'N'
    constant_names = 'Nth  E_AC'
    constant_expressions = '0.3  0.05' #[nm^-3] [eV]
    expression = 'if(N>Nth, 0, -E_AC/Nth*N + E_AC)'
    execute_on = 'initial linear timestep_end'
  []

  ######## Electric END ########
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]

  ######## Electric #######

  #  [./Resistance]
  #    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
  #    function = resistance_func
  #  [../]

  [average_V]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = V
    boundary = 'top'
  []

  [average_Jy]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = Jy
    boundary = 'bottom'
  []

  [Current]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    function = "if(average_Jy>0,average_Jy*${xmax}, -average_Jy*${xmax})"
    pp_names = average_Jy
  []
  ######## Electric END #######
[]

[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]


[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = 'JFNK'

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre      boomeramg'

  l_max_its = 50
  nl_max_its = 50

  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8

  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 1.0
  dt = 5e-4
  dtmin = 1e-7

  automatic_scaling = true
  compute_scaling_once = false
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  file_base = output
[]


Thank you
Jeonghwan

Thank you very much!
Unfortunately, I added your suggestion but converging is also failed.
Do you think still the reason that my simulation does not converge only at 450, 500K is the Jacobian? any other reasons?
Also, I would be appreciated it if you teach me where I can find how to calculate and implement Jacobian(also OffDiagJacobian).
I tried to learn it but the MOOSE tutorial taught me it very briefly or told me to use AD.
Why don't you use AD?
You can use the petsc command line options -snes_test_jacobian -snes_test_jacobian_view to find problems in your Jacobian

Thank you very much!
I will try to use AD or check other issues.

Oh I just noticed something. By default for PJFNK your preconditioning matrix only has diagonal blocks filled. To get the off-diagonal part into the system matrix you need to add this in your input file
[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

The full = true line will make sure to use the "full" matrix, including both on- and off-diagonal blocks
Thanks for your kindness!!

node.title: Why did I encounter a mistake about segmentation fault?

When I run the program, I get the following error about segmentation fault. This error still occurs when I change 'motar' to 'panelty'. How can I debug it?

There s a debugging page on the moose website you can use if you don’t have experience with that

node.title: Need help with parameter study on 10,000 different Voronoi meshes.
node.bodyText:
My team is attempting to run a parameter study that will generate 10,000 different meshes and perform a single time step on each. We have looked at the Parameter study tutorial on the website and have modified the code for our application, but when we attempted to run it, we got an error message claiming that the input file has no actionable object. What could be causing this error?
Second, how would one generate a discrete distribution of parameters (e.g. 1, 2, 3...)? We are attempting to do a parameter study where the parameter varied is the random seed number.
I have included the following code of the input file:
[ParameterStudy]
  input = MOOSE_10_grains_Stochastic.i
  parameters = 'UserObjects/voronoi/rand_seed'
  # quantities_of_interest = 'T_avg/value q_left/value'

  sampling_type = lhs
  num_samples = 10000
  distributions = 'uniform'
  uniform_lower_bound = 1
  uniform_upper_bound = 20000
[]
@zachmprince

So the first issue is probably a bug in the way it automatically determines the multiapp_mode parameter. So I would just set this manually. The safest one is multiapp_mode = batch-reset, but I would need to see the input to suggest the best one.
For the discrete sampling, there isn't a way to do this in the sampler. But one thing you can do is have this in MOOSE_10_grains_Stochastic.i:
rand_seed_real = 0.0 # Dummy value to be replaced by sampling
rand_seed = ${fparse int(rand_seed_real)}

[UserObjects]
  [voronoi]
    ...
    rand_seed = ${rand_seed} 
  []
[]

Then you would just perturb rand_seed_real in ParameterStudy/parameters:
[ParameterStudy]
  input = MOOSE_10_grains_Stochastic.i
  multiapp_mode = batch-reset
  parameters = 'rand_seed_real'
  # quantities_of_interest = 'T_avg/value q_left/value'

  sampling_type = lhs
  num_samples = 10000
  distributions = 'uniform'
  uniform_lower_bound = 1
  uniform_upper_bound = 20000
[]

Doing this requires multiapp_mode = batch-reset.
Unfortunately, we have implemented your fixes and are getting the same error: "section "ParameterStudy" does not have an associated "Action.""

How old is your moose version?
Is your app including the stochastic tools module?

We are using the latest version and have installed the app on the StochasticTools module. He have tried everything and we don't know what to do to fix the issue. We're at the end of our rope. If there anything you can suggest we do, please share it.

What do you mean by installed the app on the module?
This does not seem right. To create an app, you need to use the stork script in moose/scripts and then enable every physics module you need in the Makefile
Apologies, I misspoke. I meant that we had enabled the StochasticTools module while running the latest version.

And your rebuilt (make) the executable after enabling the module right
what does ldd <your_executable-opt> return (on linux) ?

can you please paste your make file here

Here is the makefile, sorry for the delay.
Makefile.txt

can you git clean -xfd then rebuild?
you have the right command in the Makefile to enable stochastic_tools

Apologies for the delay. We've been trying to figure out other solutions to the problem, but after seeing a past user who encountered a similar issue, I'm wondering if the problem lies in the base script itself. I've posted it here, please take a look to see if there's anything that wouldn't play well with StochasticTools.
MOOSE_10_grains_Stochastic.txt
@zachmprince

node.title: How to achieve finite volume in Moose？
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone, may I ask two questions?
I want to implement the finite volume method in moose, may I ask which modules need to be mobilized?
And how to realize mapping for non-finite element discrete physical field in MOOSE?
Thank you very much！
Lily

Hello
Finite volume is in the framework, it can be utilized in any module.
The navier stokes module is currently the only example using finite volume
Where is the non-finite element discrete field coming from? Does it have an analytical form?
Guillaume

Sorry,I don't make myself clear enough. In other words，how does moose implement finite element to infinite element mapping?
Lily
Not sure. Libmesh has a concept of infinite element you ll want to have a look at their website maybe ask on the libmesh discussions forum

Thank you!
Lily
@roystgnr

I've never actually used the infinite elements capability myself.  It's got a bit of test coverage in libMesh that does double duty as usage examples: miscellaneous examples 1, 14, and 15 ... but has it ever been used in MOOSE?  It's a non-default configuration option and I don't think it's one that the default MOOSE libMesh build script has enabled ... and although MOOSE users can work with a custom-configured libMesh, git grep InfElemBuilder isn't showing me anything in MOOSE, and I think a meshgenerator calling on that would have been the very first thing a user would have added.  It wouldn't have been the last thing, though; the Sobolev-weighted quadrature needed for element assembly is slightly different too.

Thank you for your answer. It's very enlightening.
Lily

node.title: Putting function is MatAnisoDiffusion
node.bodyText:
I am working on multi-phase field model.  I need to use 2 diffusion rate tensors for 2 different conditions. Am I providing the command correctly or do I need to change anything?
[diff_cCu]
    type = MatAnisoDiffusion
    variable = c
    diffusivity = 'if(hCu>0.8, D_bulk, D_int)' 
    v = cCu
    args = 'etaCu'
    material_property_names = 'hCu'
  [ ]

Hello
You cant put an expression for the diffusivity parameter. it has to be the name of a material property.
Please use this object instead to define that property:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ParsedMaterial.html
